<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
In an experiment on \(\alpha \)-particle scattering, \(\alpha \)-particles are directed at a thin gold foil. Most of the \(\alpha \)-particles pass straight through the foil or are deflected by a small angle. A small number of \(\alpha \)-particles are deflected by a large angle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 134, 608, 153]]<|/det|>
Which statement **cannot** be deduced from this experiment?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 163, 134, 180]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 163, 413, 180]]<|/det|>
Atoms are mostly empty space.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 190, 134, 207]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 189, 645, 207]]<|/det|>
Most of the mass of an atom is concentrated in the nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 216, 134, 234]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 216, 494, 234]]<|/det|>
The nucleus of an atom contains protons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 242, 134, 260]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 241, 690, 259]]<|/det|>
The nucleus of an atom is small compared to the size of an atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 286, 106, 304]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 285, 405, 304]]<|/det|>
Four nuclei are represented below.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 317, 608, 339]]<|/det|>
\[^{28}_{14}\mathrm{E}\qquad^{25}_{15}\mathrm{G}\qquad^{25}_{12}\mathrm{M}\qquad^{24}_{13}\mathrm{Q}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 352, 504, 370]]<|/det|>
Which statement about these nuclei is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 381, 134, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 381, 630, 399]]<|/det|>
An uncharged atom of element Q has 24 orbital electrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 408, 134, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 408, 567, 426]]<|/det|>
Nuclei G and M are isotopes of the same element.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 435, 134, 453]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 435, 784, 452]]<|/det|>
When E absorbs a neutron and then emits an \(\alpha\)-particle, E transforms into M.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 461, 134, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 460, 554, 479]]<|/det|>
When M emits a \(\beta^{- }\) particle, M transforms into Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 505, 104, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 504, 920, 539]]<|/det|>
A neutron is composed of one up (u) quark and two down (d) quarks. When a neutron decays to a proton, a beta-particle is emitted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 550, 912, 567]]<|/det|>
What is the change in the quark structure of the neutron due to the emission of the beta-particle?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 584, 628, 602]]<|/det|>
(The symbol for a neutrino is \(\nu_{\mathrm{e}}\) and for an antineutrino is \(\overline{\nu}_{\mathrm{e}}\) .)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 617, 134, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 617, 314, 635]]<|/det|>
d \(\rightarrow\) u + \(\beta^{- }\) + \(\nu_{\mathrm{e}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 644, 134, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 644, 314, 663]]<|/det|>
d \(\rightarrow\) u + \(\beta^{- }\) + \(\overline{\nu}_{\mathrm{e}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 674, 134, 693]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 674, 314, 693]]<|/det|>
u \(\rightarrow\) d + \(\beta^{+} + \nu_{\mathrm{e}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 703, 134, 722]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 703, 314, 722]]<|/det|>
u \(\rightarrow\) d + \(\beta^{+} + \overline{\nu}_{\mathrm{e}}\)
